CP(1) General Commands Manual CP(1)

NAME

cp — copy files and directories

SYNOPSIS

cp [-dfipRr] source target

cp [-dfipRr] source ... directory

DESCRIPTION

The cp utility copies the contents of source to target. If target is a directory, then the source is copied into target with its original filename. If multiple sources are provided, they are copied into the target directory.

The options are as follows:

-d
Do not follow symbolic links in the source. When this option is specified, symbolic links are copied as symbolic links, not the files they reference.
-f
Force copy by removing the destination if it cannot be opened for writing.
-i
Prompt for confirmation before overwriting existing files.
-p
Preserve file mode, ownership, and timestamps.
-R, -r
Copy directories recursively. If this option is not specified, cp will not copy directories.

EXAMPLES

Copy file1 to file2:

$ cp file1 file2

Copy a directory recursively:

$ cp -r source_dir target_dir

Copy a symbolic link without following it:

$ cp -d symlink new_symlink

Copy with preserved attributes:

$ cp -p file1 file2

EXIT STATUS

The cp utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

SEE ALSO

mv(1), ln(1), chmod(1), rsync(1)

STANDARDS

The cp utility attempts to be compatible with the IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (“POSIX.1”) specification, with additional support for modern features like symbolic link handling.

August 2, 2025 macOS 15.6
